q: Does Swami speak about The Matrix movie?
a: While Swami Sarvapriyananda does not directly reference the movie The Matrix in the provided lecture, he does touch upon a concept that is similar to one of the film's central themes. When discussing the story of Swami Sivananda, who was a disciple of Sri Ramakrishna, Swami Sarvapriyananda talks about how Swami Sivananda, after having a stroke and becoming partially paralyzed, distinguished between his true self (the unaffected) and his physical body (the affected). This idea of a separate, unchanging self that exists beyond the physical world is reminiscent of the red pill/blue pill choice presented to the character Neo in The Matrix. In the movie, taking the red pill represents choosing to see the harsh reality that the world is actually a simulated one, while taking the blue pill means living in blissful ignorance within the simulated world. Similarly, Swami Sivananda chose to recognize the distinction between his true self (the unaffected) and his physical body (the affected), rather than identifying solely with his physical condition.
